utterances: …while McCain has a free and clear shot at the center.
And that's going to be in places you would think like Alabama and Georgia.
Well, that's exactly right.

And Huckabee doesn't have to win or even finish second or even a close third to dramatically undermine Romney's chances because you've - aside from the more basic centrist conservatives split in the party, you still got these pretty hardcore of McCain haters.
And to the extent that Huckabee takes some of those out of Romney's column, that's a problem for Romney and an advantage for McCain.
And there's certainly no love lost between Huckabee and Romney.
Romney spent a lot of time calling Huckabee a liberal, so I don't think that Huckabee feels like he's in any hurry to do any - Romney any favors by pulling out of the race.
Well, Huckabee, Thompson, Giuliani, and of course, McCain, none of them have a particularly great deal of love for Mitt Romney.

And it looks like Giuliani is endorsing McCain with a particular amount of relish, and I suspect that Fred Thompson will weigh in for McCain when he and McCain decide it will do the most good for them and the most damage for Romney.
So…
Which raises - leaves the question: How does John McCain make up to those McCain haters, a lot of them the conservatives in the Republican Party?
Well, as long as Mike Huckabee's around, it's slightly more achievable because all those voters are not consolidating behind one single candidate.
That's a huge advantage for him.
What he does is what he's, you know, been doing for the last several weeks, and he's been making inroads and making progress.
He talks a lot of national security.
As the debate has shifted the economy, he has repeated the phrase foot soldier in the Reagan revolution one million times in the last three weeks.
And he does his best to stay away from issues like campaign finance reform, like global warming and most importantly like immigration.
They've really caused some problems with the base.

If I can just add very quickly here, that while this is a - McCain isn't in a very strong position right now, I think the other advantage that Romney has with him is - if he chooses to use it - is the immigration issue.
In California, Republican voters here ranked not the economy, not national security, but immigration as the issue of most - important to them.
And while McCain took a huge amount of grief from voters and from talk show hosts last summer, Romney really hasn't gone at him on that issue in a sustained way.
I suspect if Romney is going to get back into this race in tonight's debate, you're going to hear the word amnesty over and over and over again.
And if he doesn't say it, Rush Limbaugh will probably will.
Dan Schnur, thank you very much.
Thanks for having me.
I enjoyed it.
Dan Schnur, a Republican strategist, executive vice president of Edelman, a public relations firm.
He spoke to us on the phone from Los Angeles.
Well, plenty of time left for your calls with the Political Junkie.
Ken Rudin is going to stay with us.
E-mail us, talk@npr.org.
Today, we're talking with the Political Junkie, Ken Rudin, about what's coming this Tuesday.
Super Tuesday, two dozen states weigh in in primaries and caucuses all across the country.
If you'd like to join us, 800-989-8255.
E-mail us, talk@npr.org.
You can also read whatever listeners have to say on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
And of course, Ken, we can't leave out American Samoa and Democrats abroad.
No, even though - we shouldn't.
No. Although, we don't talk about abroad because Bill Clinton gets in trouble with that.
Let's get some callers on the line here.
Okay.
Let's go to Mark(ph).
And Mark is with us from Lake City in Florida.
Yes, sir.
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
You'd help bail us out.
I'm a longtime Southern white Democrat, and I voted for Hillary Clinton.
And I've talked to a lot of friends, and we're just not, you know, if it comes down to Obama as being the candidate, and that - we don't - we won't vote for him for a number of reasons.
And we think that McCain probably is more palatable to us as a Republican candidate than it would be Obama as a Democrat.
You mentioned several reasons, any number of reasons why you would not vote for Barack Obama.
What might them - what might they be?
Well, number one is he's an eloquent speaker, but there's no - I don't see any substance there.
Number two is his race.
It comes - it plays a factor whether you say it does or doesn't, and I'm just, you know, you want to have a good feeling about him, but you don't, you know, so I'm…
So you…
I'm just wondering…
…you and the people you're talking to, you're not ready to vote for an African-American for president?
No.
To be honest with you, no. And there's a lot of us that feel that way, to be honest with you.
Okay.
Thanks very much for the call, Mark.
Appreciate it.
Thank you, Neal.
Bye-bye.
Ken?
Well, I mean, you know, we don't talk about that as much.
I mean, obviously, the race issue came into play during South Carolina.
We saw both sides playing it to some extent, perhaps the Clintons more so.
But this is something that - it's out there.

And of course, for all the polls that showed that 40, 45 percent of the Democrats would never vote for Hillary Clinton in November, you have to wonder about, you know, how people feel about Barack Obama.
The experience issue is a thing.
He's only been a senator a couple of years, although he does have experience in the Illinois State Legislature.
But it's going to look paltry if his candidacy is opposed to that of John McCain.
Well, see the - what's interesting also is that I thought from the beginning that Barack Obama was not - he was not the Jesse Jackson/Al Sharpton African-American candidate.
Not a movement candidate.
Exactly.
He was somebody who hoped to rise above race, if there's such a thing in this day and age, and perhaps bring race together.
But I thought some of the vitriolic language and the rhetoric that came out of South Carolina almost portrayed Barack Obama as the black candidate.
So whether we are under any illusions that race would not play an issue.
Certainly more on the forefront we saw after South Carolina.
Yet a lot of people said after Iowa - not a big African-American state…
Nope.
(Unintelligible).
…by any stretch or New Hampshire for that matter.
That those - that was in the past, that they appear to shatter that illusion.
Well, except they only had to deal with the rhetoric in South Carolina would have came back to the forefront again.

And of course, we do see a lot of - I mean, it's interesting to see how many people who would have voted for John Edwards where they go, especially in Deep South states - Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia, and things like that.
And let's go to Jim(ph).
And Jim is calling us from Spencer in Iowa.
Yes.
Hello.
Hi, Jim.
Well, I guess, I would reassure people that Iowa's first-in-the-nation caucus is really not going to ruin the political process in Iowa.
I think, you know, there's a lot more concerned about the candidate that would be best for the country than people might actually realize.
I think if people want to be first in the nation, that they'd be better prepared for all of the phone calls and all the mail and just the hassle it is.
It's not as much fun as they might think.
And the TV advertising, nice for the broadcasting stations, but not so nice for the viewers.
No, it's a lot of responsibility.
And it's a lot of trouble.

But anyway, I guess that now that Edwards has backed out, I guess I would have to - as a member of the cultural community, a person of the creative class - I think that I would have to support Mr. Obama.
Did you support Mr. Edwards in the Iowa caucuses?
Yes.

I'm a delegate, and I have to decide and I'm thinking - well, you know, Mr. Edwards, you know, coming from a rural state, you would think that his philosophy would be something that the little guy out here would embrace.
But I think that farmers have gotten little too big for that in some regards.

As a member of the creative class of artists, and that's something that Mr. Obama is committed to - is, you know, helping people who are part of the creative economy and that's why I was supporting Mr. Edwards, though.
Now, if - you're a delegate, you say.
How do you notify somebody that you're planning to support him?
Do you send him a telegram or, you know, e-mail or what?
Well, that's my call.
And you know, it hasn't gotten to the point of who exactly goes to the convention.
But I could, I suppose.
And you know, those individuals who were willing to vote for me as their delegate were also willing to give me the decision to make us to, you know, whether I would change my vote.
